sections.title: Implant-retained dentures FAQs
sections.body:
Implant-retained dentures are dentures that are stabilised using dental implants placed in the jaw.

They are designed for people who find conventional dentures unstable or uncomfortable, but who are not suitable for — or do not want — fully fixed implant teeth. This approach sits between standard removable dentures and fixed implant solutions.

Understanding what implant-retained dentures can and cannot do helps you decide whether they are an appropriate step for your needs.
bullets: Dentures that don’t slip or lift
Fewer implants than full fixed bridges

sections.title: Planned implant care you can rely on
How implant-retained dentures work
sections.body:
Implant-retained dentures use a small number of dental implants to help anchor a removable denture more securely.

The denture clips or attaches onto the implants, improving stability compared with a traditional denture that rests on the gums alone. The denture is still removable for cleaning and maintenance.

This combination of implants and a removable denture aims to improve comfort and function without the complexity of a fully fixed solution.

sections.title: Who may benefit
items: Implant-retained dentures may be suitable for people who struggle with loose dentures and have sufficient bone to support implants.
They may not be appropriate where medical conditions, smoking, bone levels, or oral health make implant placement unsuitable. Cost and ongoing maintenance are also important considerations.
We assess suitability carefully and will discuss alternatives if another approach is likely to be more appropriate.

sections.title: Typically
items: Treatment involves placing dental implants, allowing time for healing, and then fitting a denture designed to attach securely to those implants.
This is a staged process that takes place over several months rather than a single appointment. During this time, temporary solutions may be used.
We explain each stage clearly so you understand the timescales, commitments, and likely outcomes before treatment begins.

sections.title: Digital planning for predictable outcomes
sections.body:
Compared with conventional dentures, implant-retained dentures are usually more stable, particularly during eating and speaking.

Because some of the support comes from implants, there is often less reliance on suction or muscle control alone. However, they remain removable appliances and do not feel the same as natural teeth or fixed implant restorations.

This difference is important to understand when considering expectations and long-term comfort.

sections.title: Aftercare, healing, and long-term care
items: Implant-retained dentures require daily cleaning and regular professional review to maintain both the denture and the implants supporting it.
Although implants are not affected by decay, the surrounding gums and bone can be. Long-term success depends on good oral hygiene and ongoing maintenance.
We discuss these responsibilities in detail so you understand what is involved beyond the initial treatment.

faqs.question: How are they cleaned and maintained?
faqs.answer:
Cleaning involves removing the denture, cleaning it thoroughly, and cleaning around the implants in the mouth.

We’ll explain practical techniques and review them regularly to help prevent problems.

Attachments and components may need periodic replacement as part of normal maintenance.

faqs.question: Are implant-retained dentures the same as fixed teeth?
faqs.answer: No. They are removable dentures that are stabilised by implants, not permanently fixed teeth.

faqs.question: How many implants are needed?
faqs.answer: The number of implants is planned after assessment and scans, often fewer than a full fixed bridge requires while still providing reliable support.

faqs.question: Are they removable?
faqs.answer: Many implant-retained dentures are designed to be removed for daily cleaning while staying secure during eating and speaking. Suitability depends on your specific plan.

faqs.question: Will they feel bulky?
faqs.answer: The denture is crafted to balance stability with comfort. We review fit and make adjustments so it feels as natural and streamlined as possible.

faqs.question: Does the procedure hurt?
faqs.answer: Implant placement is carried out with local anaesthetic and a calm approach. Some pressure and post-treatment soreness are expected, with clear guidance to keep you comfortable.

faqs.question: How long do they last?
faqs.answer: Implants are intended for long-term use, but longevity depends on healing, home care, and attending regular reviews to monitor implant health and denture fit.

faqs.question: How much does treatment cost?
faqs.answer: Costs are discussed after a full assessment and planning stage, with transparent explanations of options so you know the investment before deciding.

faqs.question: Can I upgrade later to a fixed bridge?
faqs.answer: In some cases additional planning allows a transition to a fixed bridge later. We confirm if that pathway is realistic once we understand your bone health and goals.

sections.title: Fixed vs removable options
sections.body: Some patients ask whether they should choose a fixed implant bridge instead. The choice depends on the factors below, and we’ll explain both routes clearly so you can decide confidently.

sections.title: A realistic, supportive plan
sections.strapline: Our role is to help you choose a solution that improves comfort and function, fits your lifestyle, and can be maintained long-term. Sometimes the simpler option is the better one.
